Award.AwardTitle: RAPID Collaborative Proposal: Characterization of upland watershed contamination from wildland-urban burning

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The multi-institutional team will characterize the effects of the November 2018 Camp fire on watershed water quality. This was the most destructive wildfire in California history, resulting in 15,000 structures and thousands of vehicles burnt. The extensive amount of burned debris has resulted in concerns that the ash can transport toxic metals and organic contaminants into the surrounding waterways. The upland watershed drains directly into Lake Oroville, the largest reservoir in the California State Water Project. This reservoir provides drinking and irrigation water to millions of users. The potential for mobilization is high because precipitation-induced erosion mobilized fire debris into downstream creeks and reservoirs before clean-up could begin. This research will help us understand the concentrations and persistence of contaminants in the watershed post-fire. Such information is necessary to identify potential threats to human and ecological health. Broader impacts to society result from an increased understanding of upland fire impacts on water supplies. Such information can lead to better management strategies to protect water quality.

The Camp fire in November 2018 was the most destructive fire in California history, resulting in 15,000 structures and thousands of vehicles being burnt. There is concern that overland flow of ash and debris from burned structures, cars, and other buildings may transport toxic metals such as arsenic, copper, cadmium, mercury, lead, as well as toxic organic chemicals such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, polychlorinated biphenyls, brominated fire retardants, dioxins and other contaminants into the surrounding waterways. This is particularly important given that the watershed drains directly into Lake Oroville, the largest reservoir in the California State Water Project that provides drinking and irrigation water to millions of users. In addition to the threats to Lake Oroville, Butte Creek hosts the last stable spring run of Chinook Salmon population in all of California. The potential for contaminant mobilization following the Camp Fire is strong because precipitation occurred prior to emergency clean up, resulting in washing of fire debris into downstream creeks and reservoirs. To better characterize these potential threats, a multi-institutional team with complimentary expertise in environmental chemistry and transport will assess the concentrations of these and many other heavy metal and organic pollutants in the Camp Fire watershed for 12 months post-fire. The research team will use this information to evaluate the fate and transport of contaminants from the burn area. Specific research will seek to understand 1) how does burning, ash deposition, and rainfall influence contaminant mobilization within the urban area and in downstream waters, 2) how long will contaminants persist in the watershed post-fire, and 3) what are the acute and chronic threats to human and aquatic health associated with contaminant mobilization into surrounding surface waters. The results of this research will improve our understanding of contaminant fate, persistence, and transport following burning. This information will help urban/rural planners, as well as forest and watershed managers to better identify, mitigate, and reduce threats to water quality resulting from forest fires.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2018 Camp Fire (Paradise, CA) was the deadliest and most destructive fire in California history, claiming 86 lives and destroying 18,000 structures in the Town of Paradise and surrounding communities. Following the fire, the burned urban environment took nearly a year to clean up, during which time numerous winter storms caused surface runoff from the area, potentially contaminating the local waterways and groundwater with urban disaster material remaining exposed prior to removal.  To evaluate the extent of the water quality impacts of the wildfire, three watersheds draining Paradise, as well as an unburned control watershed, were sampled throughout the water-year from November 2018 to December 2019.  In total, nearly 160 unique time-location samples were collected, these were analyzed for known stormwater contaminants and general water quality characteristics.

In a subset of samples, we comprehensively characterized organic contaminant profiles and dynamics via targeted quantification of 35 stormwater-derived chemicals with complementary high resolution mass spectrometry suspect screening. For quantified analytes, pentachlorophenol, a wood preservative pesticide and a likely human carcinogen, dominated the chemical profiles with concentrations up to 2400 ng/L and detection frequency of 89%. At times, detected pentachlorophenol concentrations exceeded maximum contaminant levels for drinking waters.  In one sampling site close to a burned pharmacy store, 6400 ng/L of ibuprofen and 1500 ng/L of caffeine were detected; suspect screening also revealed acetaminophen and lidocaine presence. Similar pharmaceuticals were detected at other locations.  Complementary suspect screening also revealed high levels of perfluorinated compounds in samples collected during the storms compared with other samples collected over the water year.

In the surface water samples, Zn and Ba were measured with highest frequency and were present in all samples. Nickel was found in over 95% of samples, and Cu, Pb, were detected in over half of all samples, while As, Cd were not detected with high frequency (around 5%).  Concentrations of Zn and Ba were also the highest of all metals with median values ranging from around 9 - 20 μg/L for both metals.  Median concentrations of Co, Cr, Cu, Pb ranged from about 0.1 to 10 μg/L across all metals and watersheds. The burned watersheds tended to have 10-fold increases in median concentrations for all metals across burned watersheds when compared to the control watershed.  In comparison to pre-fire data collected over the 2003/2004 water year, the small streams directly draining the burned town of Paradise (Clear Creek and Dry Creek) consistently had median trace metal concentrations around 10-fold higher than the historical data, with some samples being orders of magnitude higher.  Pb and Zn concentrations tended to have the greatest increases, with a nearly 1000-fold increase in Zn in both watersheds. The highest Pb concentration measured was about 10 μg/L, while the highest Zn concentration was close to 800 μg/L.  Metal concentrations in surface water appear to be driven by particulates such as sediments mobilized during storm events.

Aqueous Hg levels remained relatively low (<15 ng/L) within one week of the fire containment. With more intensive storms in the later winter months (December 2018 through May 2019), Hg levels tended to only be slightly elevated in streams (up to 27 ng/L) but reached up to 500 ng/L in one stream suspected to be contaminated from historical gold mining activities. We also found that Hg transport was mainly driven by suspended solids, and the Hg per unit mass of suspended solids was in general lower in streams draining from burned landscapes (31.2 - 65.4 ng/g) than in the reference stream (78.2 ng/g), indicating that Hg volatilization may be substantial during fire events.

Flushing effects of storm runoff from burned and unburned watersheds seemed to differ throughout the winter season based on burning occurrence. In a reference unburned watershed, dissolved organic carbon (DOC) levels decreased throughout the year while the burned watersheds continued to be a source of elevated DOC throughout the water year.  The character of the organic matter, measured by absorbance and normalized to the DOC concentrations, indicates burned watershed continued to be a source of aromatic molecules throughout the storm season, and this was higher in watersheds with a greater amount of burning. The results indicate the effects of burn events on general water quality parameters like DOC were persistent.

Interestingly, there is a strong relationship between total dissolved nitrogen (mainly as nitrate) and degree of urban burning in the watersheds.    In burned watersheds, total dissolved nitrogen concentrations were similar to, and sometimes exceeded, DOC concentrations, which is unusual in freshwaters. The elevated nitrogen observations also persisted throughout the water year.

The Camp Fire had a short-term, acute effect on potentially toxic organic compounds while also affecting long-term water quality trends for many toxic metals, dissolved organic carbon (especially aromatic compounds), and total dissolved nitrogen (mainly nitrate); however, the concentrations were rarely elevated beyond the EPA's aquatic toxicity standards.
